Syndrome Decoding

  //   Topics: Coding Theory

Syndrome

Let \(\pmb {C}\) be a linear code with parity check matrix \(\pmb {H}\).

For any vector \(\pmb {\vec v \in V(n, q)}\), the syndrome of \(\pmb {\vec v}\) is \(\pmb {\vec v H^T}\).

If \(\pmb {\vec v \in C}\), then \(\pmb {\vec v H^T = \vec 0}\). Otherwise, \(\pmb {\vec v H^T \neq \vec 0}\).

For any two vectors \(\pmb {\vec v, \vec u \in V(n, q)}\), it holds that \(\pmb {\vec v H^T = \vec u H^T}\) if and only if \(\pmb {\vec v}\) and \(\pmb {\vec u}\) are in the same coset of \(\pmb {C}\). Therefore, the syndrome of a vector is enough to determine which coset it lies in, and vice versa.
